section.hand: Copie of a letter to my L. Treasurer May 25. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 15 May To my L Treasurer
It may please yo
r
L. yesterday I Rxd hir
Ma
ties
lett
r
of the 2 of this
moneth, & in
e same pacquete 2 from yo
r
L one of the 1 and anoth
r
of the 5 of
e same. wh
r
unto for aunswear yt may please yo
r
L. to advertise
hir Highnes, that wh
r
as by yo
r
s it appeareth, that form
r
l
re
s have bin sent
unto me about my dealing w
th
e states for
e Towne of
Ostend,
there have no
such l
re
s come to my hand
, onely 3 weeks synce I was written unto from
S
r
John Conwaie
, & th
r
uppon sollicited the
states
very ernestly, so as they
tooke p
nt
order aswell for fortefyeng
e towne, as for fournishing of yt oth
r
wise
w
th
munition & victuals: wherof I would have sent present word to yo
r
L
but
t
I was suddenlye cast downe w
th
an extreame dissentry, w
ch
made me
unable for
e time to shew any diligence in my service. And now consydering
e
states had already don
t
, w
ch
her Ma
ty
desyred I stood in some doubt of
acquainting them w
th
her writing. Nev
r
theles for the bett
r
assurance of my
owne discharge, & for
t
I know theyr [rechelesnes] in
e execution of
theyr owne resolutions, I thought best to frame a proposition unto them
in such order as I send yo
r
L in
e copy heerinclosed. Wherto I cannot say
for theyr answear, because I am deputed w
th
others to de
t
is p
nt
daie
for
Berghen up Zoome
. For such causes as I signified 4 dayes past to
M
r
Secretary
, but I will send yt after w
th
the fyrst opportunitye.
In my Jo
r
ney toward Berghen I purpose to take
Dordrecht
in my way
& to deale w
th
e magistrates about
e release of
S
r
John Wingfield
childe.
Wherin I would have don my best before now, but
t
I was
nev
r
otherwyse informed of
e case
but
by a common brute, w
th
out message
or lett
r
from any
t
had charge of
e childe. Likewyse at my coming
to Berghen I will advise w
th
the Countesse & her friend
by what meanes
I may work S
r
John Wingfield deliv
r
ance, w
ch
I cannot now imagine
how I may compas. besydes
t
it will stand me uppon to walke very
warely about yt, in respect of
e tender humor of the states.
For I am now but in a competent credyt among them, & yf yt should
come to theyr knowledge
t
I do practise his deliverance, yo
r
L. will
hardly beleave, how much they would stomack me & what conceat
they
will multiply uppon yt. w
ch
I do
tly attribut to a malitious app
r
hensyon
w
ch
is among
m for
is p
nt
against o
r
nation in generall: but in truthe
I fynde yt by experience, & ev
r
ydaye more,
t
a principall cause of
theyr straunge consultations & courses ys the very Defect & imperfection
of moste of theyr judgement
. I know, theyr continuall excercyse in
fol.227v
matt
r
of state &
e common opinion
t
goeth of theyr wysdome may
seeme to argue
e contrary as also oth
r
ministers of hir Ma
ty
,
t
have
negotiated w
th
them in plausible causes or not as I have had in charge
in suche a nomb
r
of matters
t
might greatly distaste them, may
have oth
r
wyse conceaved of theyr sufficiency, but me think
, for myne
owne
te, I do see theyr weakenes so apparaunt, & in so many matters
& continually, as I cannot chuse but in their pryvat sort to yo
r
L
to censure them for yt. I should be very sory to und
r
stand that
my
L. of Buchurst
journey is staied by
e coming of
e Deputyes
for his p
nc
e here above oth
r
s hath bin chiefly desyred, & is daily now
expected uppon hir Ma
ties
writing, It is ev
r
y mans opinion,
t
some
speciall good will come of yt, &
e common people will be greatly
hartened when [
e] shall see hir Ma
tyes
care of theyr welfare so
gratiously continewed. Moreover I am fully
swaded
t
the
deputyes gon for
England
ar so weakly authorised, that theyr being
there ys but litle bett
r
then so much lesse of tyme, & a cause of great
r
dang
r
to
es countryes, where
e goverm
t
requireth a very speedy
Reformation & may by theyr dalyance be put in some hazard.
I have made
em here
takers of yo
r
L adv
r
tisement
from
Bruxelles
of
e [reconing]
t
Parma
maketh to have so many townes of
Holland
at his devotion. w
ch
notw
th
standing I hope will prove but a bruit,
for I see no inclination in any to deale so farr w
th
e Ennemy.
S
r
Martin Schenck
hath bin here
es 3 weekes & ys almost come
to a fynall accord w
th
e states, but yet
ey have not resolved to
confer
e Marshals offyce uppon him, I do not doubt but
e report
of Parmaes death is come to yo
r
L w
ch
is almost assured is heer
by L
re
s from
Andwerp
& Bruxels, but
e Authors credyt is not suche
t
we can hold yt for certayne, & yet
e adv
r
tisement of his deadly
sicknes hath bin often continued by sondry mens l
re
s. yt is also written
heth
r
t
the governo
r
of
Cambray
hath declared himself for
e
French king
but we have yt not yet w
th
good confirmac
o
n. I have made
e
counsell
of State very glad w
th
yo
r
L. newes of
Scotland
&
Fraunce,
w
ch
we trust
ere be long wilbe accompanyed w
th
like good tiding
from
e English
fleet; so as all
e world shall see
Diligientibus Deum o
i
a cooperanj
in bonum
. &c./
